title: Compensatory Training to Support Everyday Function and Adherence to Brain Healthy Lifestyle Changes in Those at Risk for Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The Researchers are trying to better understand if behavioral interventions can help improve memory compensation and engagement in healthy lifestyle behaviors in those with memory concerns but normal mental status exam.
explanation_target: Reason: The study tests behavioral/rehabilitation interventions (compensatory training and lifestyle-change support) in people with subjective memory concerns but normal cognitive testing — it is not testing a drug or biologic. citeturn0search0turn0search7

Act (key details extracted): The registered trial lists interventions as 'Behavioral: Cognitive rehabilitation and health behavior change intervention' and 'Behavioral: Self-implementation' with primary aims to evaluate acceptability, memory compensation use, and adherence to brain-healthy lifestyle changes. citeturn0search7turn0search5

Supporting evidence / context: Protocols and related publications describe digital app–supported compensatory training and lifestyle-modification programs (e.g., the Brain Boosters / EMMA interventions) that target compensation strategies and healthy behaviors rather than pharmacologic mechanisms. These publications frame the approach as behavioral/cognitive rehabilitation. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Reflect: Given the category definitions (1: disease-targeted biologic; 2: disease-targeted small molecule; 3: cognitive enhancer — defined as drugs; 4: neuropsychiatric symptom improvement), this trial does not fit any of the four drug- or symptom-focused categories because it is a non-pharmacologic behavioral intervention. Therefore the correct classification is 'N/A'. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Web search results used (titles/sources): 'A Study to Evaluate Compensatory Training to Support Everyday Function and Adherence to Brain Healthy Lifestyle Changes in Those at Risk for Alzheimer's Disease' — Mayo Clinic trial page. citeturn0search0; 'Compensatory Training to Support Brain Healthy Lifestyle Changes in Those at Risk for Alzheimer’s Disease' — clinical trial registry entries (NCT04118985 / ICH GCP / MedPath). citeturn0search7turn0search5; 'Memory support training and lifestyle modifications to promote healthy aging...' — BMC Geriatrics (Brain Boosters protocol). citeturn0search2; 'Compensation training and lifestyle modifications to promote healthy aging...' — Alzheimer's & Dementia / Wiley abstract. citeturn0search1; 'A Combined Treatment Approach to Support Everyday Function and Promote Brain Health in Older Adults: A Pilot Study' — PubMed. citeturn0search3
